AI- generated DPWG Recommendation: CYP2C9 Poor Metabolizer:
Individuals with a Poor Metabolizer status for CYP2C9 typically have little to no enzyme activity.
This may result in slower metabolism of fluvastatin, leading to higher plasma concentrations of the drug and a potential increase in the risk of side effects.
Dose adjustment, alternative medication, or careful monitoring might be necessary.
SLCO1B1 Poor Function:
The SLCO1B1 gene encodes a protein involved in transporting fluvastatin into the liver.
Poor function in this transporter may reduce the liver uptake of fluvastatin, leading to further increased levels of the drug in the plasma, and potentially a higher risk of side effects like muscle toxicity (myopathy).
Additional caution, careful monitoring, dose adjustment, or an alternative therapy might be appropriate.
The combination of CYP2C9 Poor Metabolizer status with SLCO1B1 Poor Function could compound the effect, leading to even higher plasma concentrations of fluvastatin and a significant risk of adverse effects.
Official DPWG Recommendation: NO action is required for this gene-drug interaction.
The gene variation increases the plasma concentration of fluvastatin, but there is insufficient evidence to prove an effect on efficacy or side effects.

CYP2D6 UMatomoxetineEfficacy can be reduced due to the gene variation. The gene variation results in an increased conversion of atomoxetine to the active metabolite 4-hydroxyatomoxetine, which has a much lower plasma concentration. As a result, the plasma concentration of the active ingredients decreases.- Be extra alert to reduced efficacy of the treatment.
- Advise the patient to report an inadequate effect.
- An alternative can be selected as a precaution. Clonidine is not metabolised by CYP2D6.
CYP2D6 IMatomoxetineThe dose requirement can be reduced, because the genetic variation results in a higher atomoxetine plasma concentration.In the event of side effects occurring and/or a response later than 9 weeks: reduce the dose and check whether the effect is conserved The plasma concentration of atomoxetine is a factor of 2-3 times higher for IM than for NM at the same dose.
CYP2D6 PMatomoxetineThe risk of side effects is increased, because the genetic variation results in a higher atomoxetine plasma concentration.- Start with the normal initial dose, bearing in mind that an increase in this dose probably will not be required.
- Advise the patient to report side effects (such as decreased appetite, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, insomnia, early waking, drowsiness, irritability, pupil dilation and itching).
- If the medicine is effective, but side effects occur: reduce the dose and check whether the effect is conserved. The plasma concentration of atomoxetine is a factor of 8-11 times higher for PM than for NM at the same dose.

: ', 'Drug: fluvastatin

AI- generated CPIC Recommendation: For individuals with the CYP2C9 *1/*1 genotype (presumably your genotype, given the Normal Metabolizer phenotype), standard fluvastatin dosing is recommended.
However, for the SLCO1B1 gene, CPIC guidelines recommend caution when prescribing statins to individuals with a decreased function phenotype due to an increased risk of statin-associated muscle symptoms. But note, these guidelines specifically pertain to simvastatin, and specific recommendations based on SLCO1B1 function have not been issued for fluvastatin as of my last update.                                                                                                                                                            As a Normal Metabolizer for CYP2C9, you would metabolize fluvastatin at a standard rate. A SLCO1B1 phenotype of ""Poor Function"" suggests that your body is less efficient at transporting fluvastatin into the liver cells where it's metabolized, possibly leading to higher levels of the drug in your bloodstream.
Official CPIC Recommendation: Prescribe <=40mg per day as a starting dose and adjust doses of fluvastatin based on disease-specific guidelines. If patient is tolerating 40mg per day but higher potency is needed, a higher dose (>40mg) or an alternative statin or combination therapy (i.e. fluvastatin plus non-statin guideline directed medical therapy) (PMID: 30423391) could be considered. Prescriber should be aware of possible increased risk for myopathy with fluvastatin especially with doses >40mg per day.

SLCO1B1 Poor Function:

The SLCO1B1 gene encodes the organic anion-transporting polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1), which plays a role in transporting statins into the liver.
Individuals with poor function alleles of SLCO1B1 may have reduced statin uptake into the liver, leading to increased levels of the statin in the plasma and potentially a higher risk of side effects like muscle toxicity (myopathy).
While guidance specific to fluvastatin may be limited, for statins affected by SLCO1B1, it may be advisable to consider an alternative statin or closely monitor for side effects, especially muscle-related issues. A reduced dose might also be considered.

144,How do CYP2C19 and CYP2D6 influence doxepin metabolism?,Tricyclic antidepressants have comparable pharmacokinetic properties, it may be reasonable to apply the CPIC Dosing Guideline for amitriptyline and CYP2C19, CYP2D6 to other tricyclics including doxepin. The CPIC Dosing Guideline update for amitriptyline recommends an alternative drug for CYP2D6 ultrarapid or poor metabolizers and CYP2C19 ultrarapid, rapid or poor metabolizers. If amitriptyline is warranted, consider a 50% dose reduction in CYP2D6 or CYP2C19 poor metabolizers. TCAs without major CYP2C19 metabolism include the secondary amines nortriptyline and desipramine. If a tertiary amine is warranted, utilize therapeutic drug monitoring to guide dose adjustments.

: ']","CYP2C19 and CYP2D6 are enzymes that play roles in the metabolism of doxepin, a tricyclic antidepressant.

column1: 1. **CYP2D6**: This enzyme is primarily responsible for the metabolism of doxepin. Variations in the CYP2D6 gene can significantly affect how doxepin is processed in the body. For example, individuals who are intermediate metabolizers of CYP2D6 may have higher plasma concentrations of doxepin, which can increase the risk of side effects. Conversely, ultrarapid metabolizers of CYP2D6 may break down doxepin more quickly, potentially reducing its effectiveness.

2. **CYP2C19**: This enzyme contributes to a lesser extent to the metabolism of doxepin. Rapid or ultrarapid metabolizers of CYP2C19 may experience faster clearance of doxepin, which could potentially decrease the drug's efficacy. However, because CYP2C19 plays a smaller role compared to CYP2D6, its impact on doxepin pharmacokinetics is generally considered minor.

Given these influences, dose adjustments and close monitoring of the patient's response and adverse effects are recommended. In some cases, alternative medications not primarily metabolized by these enzymes may be considered.
**Confidence Score: 90%**
**References:**
- Document 1: ""Doxepin is primarily metabolized by the CYP2D6 enzyme, and to a lesser extent by CYP2C19.""

- Document 2: ""Given that the patient is an ultrarapid metabolizer of CYP2C19, it could potentially have some impact on the metabolism of doxepin but the effect is likely not as significant as alterations in CYP2D6 status because CYP2D6 is the primary enzyme responsible for its metabolism.""

- Document 3: ""Being an ultrarapid metabolizer for CYP2D6 might mean that doxepin is broken down more quickly in your body, potentially reducing its effectiveness. Rapid metabolism by CYP2C19 may further exacerbate this effect.""

Date 24-08-2016 CYP2C9*1/*2: warfarine 6228 NO action is required for this gene-drug interaction.', 'In 2007, the FDA modified the warfarin label, stating that CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotypes may be useful in determining the optimal initial dose of warfarin [Article:17906972]. The label was further updated in 2010 to include a table (Table 1) describing recommendations for initial dosing ranges for patients with different combinations of CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotypes. Genetics-based algorithms also better predict warfarin dose than the FDA-approved warfarin label table [Article:21272753]. Therefore, the use of pharmacogenetic algorithm-based dosing is recommended when possible, although if electronic means for such dosing are not available, the table-based dosing approaches (Table 1) are suggested. The range of doses by VKORC1 genotype and the range of dose recommendations/predictions by the FDA table and algorithm are shown in Figure 2."

According to the FDA guidelines, if the VKORC1 genotype is not known, the dosing can be based on the CYP2C9 genotype alone. For patients who are normal metabolizers (CYP2C9*1/*1), the recommended initial dose of warfarin is typically in the range of 5-7 mg/day. However, it is important to monitor the patient's INR (International Normalized Ratio) closely and adjust the dose accordingly to achieve the desired therapeutic effect and minimize the risk of adverse events.

\\nCYP2C19 published between January 2015 to June 2022 was reviewed and the recommendations and supplemental information were updated. Additionally, literature pertaining to CYP2B6 and sertraline published up to June 2022 was evaluated.\\n

column2: Because CPIC recommendations are provided with the assumption that the test results are available prior to prescribing, we have provided recommendations when only CYP2C19 or only CYP2B6 are available, or when both CYP2C19 and CYP2B6 genotype results are available.  Although a change in dose or therapy may not be warranted based on results for a single gene, treatment modification may be warranted given the combination of a non-normal CYP2C19 and CYP2B6 phenotype. Dosing recommendations for CYPC19/CYP2B6 and sertraline are based on Braten. et al and are based on the reported or calculated percentage differences in exposure from normal metabolizers (44).&quot

column5: i.e., citalopram, escitalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, and sertraline), serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs
column6:
i.e., desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, levomilnacipran, milnacipran, and venlafaxine), and serotonin modulators with SSRI-like properties (i.e., vilazodone and vortioxetine) are primary pharmacologic treatments for major depressive and anxiety disorders. Genetic variation in CYP2D6, CYP2C19, and CYP2B6 influences the metabolism of many of these antidepressants, which may potentially affect dosing, efficacy, and tolerability. In addition, the pharmacodynamic genes SLC6A4 (serotonin transporter) and HTR2A (serotonin-2A receptor) have been examined in relation to efficacy and side effect profiles of these drugs. This guideline updates and expands the 2015 Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) guideline for CYP2D6 and CYP2C19 genotypes and SSRI dosing and summarizes the impact of CYP2D6, CYP2C19, CYP2B6, SLC6A4, and HTR2A genotypes on antidepressant dosing, efficacy, and tolerability. We provide recommendations for using CYP2D6, CYP2C19 and CYP2B6 genotype results to help inform prescribing these antidepressants and describe the existing data for SLC6A4 and HTR2A which do not support their clinical use in antidepressant prescribing."", ""terms"": [{""id"": 1451577480, ""resource"": ""PGx Paper Types"", ""term"": ""Implementation"", ""termId"": While limited data are available for effects of CYP2C9 alleles on phenytoin metabolism in pediatric patient populations, there is no compelling data to indicate that CYP2C9 polymorphisms will affect phenytoin metabolism differently in children compared to adults. As such, the pediatric recommendation is extrapolated using adult data. Special considerations in neonates and older pediatric patients, including a high degree of dose variability and dosage forms, and evidence from pediatric populations is included in the supplement (see Pediatrics section of the Supplement for details).&quot

column38: Example diplotype:*1/*1\\nNormal phenytoin metabolism\\nNo adjustments needed from typical dosing strategies. Subsequent doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring, response, and side effects. An HLA-B*15:02 negative test']","The HLA-B and CYP2C9 status are important for phenytoin metabolism due to their significant impact on the drug's safety and efficacy:

column1: 1. **HLA-B*15:02**: This genetic variant is associated with an increased risk of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs) such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) when patients are treated with phenytoin. Therefore, identifying patients with the HLA-B*15:02 allele can help in avoiding these potentially life-threatening reactions by choosing alternative medications.

2. **CYP2C9**: This enzyme is crucial for the metabolism of phenytoin. Genetic polymorphisms in CYP2C9 can lead to variations in enzyme activity, affecting how quickly or slowly phenytoin is metabolized. For instance:

- **CYP2C9 Poor Metabolizers (PMs)**: These individuals have reduced enzyme activity, leading to slower metabolism of phenytoin, which increases the risk of toxicity. Dose adjustments are necessary to avoid adverse effects.

- **CYP2C9 Intermediate Metabolizers (IMs)**: These individuals also have reduced enzyme activity but to a lesser extent than PMs. They may still require dose adjustments, but the changes might not be as significant as for PMs.
The combination of these genetic factors helps in tailoring phenytoin therapy to minimize adverse effects and optimize therapeutic outcomes.
**Confidence Score: 95%**
**References:**

- Tassaneeyakul W et al. (2016), Ortega-Vázquez A et al. (2016), Yamamoto Y et al. (2015), Chung WH et al. (2014), Depondt C et al. (2011), Kesavan R et al. (2010), Azzato EM et al. (2010), Hennessy S et al. (2009), McCluggage LK et al. (2009), Lee SY et al. (2007), Tate SK et al. (2005), Hung CC et al. (2004), Van der Weide J et al. (2001), Ninomiya H et al. (2000), Mamiya K et al. (1998).

151,Can I start PARP inhibitors for my patient with breast cancer who has been detected with variant of uncertain significance in BRCA1?,,,"['Fluorouracil and capecitabine are not alternatives, as these are also metabolised by DPD. It is not possible to offer substantiated advice for dose reduction based on the literature. For fluorouracil and capecitabine, starting with 50 % of the standard dose is recommended. NOTE: If a patient has two different gene variations that result in a partially functional DPD enzyme (e.g. 2846T and 1236A), this recommendation only applies if the variations are on a different allele. If both variations are on the same allele, the gene activity score is between 1 and 1.5, depending on whether and how the two gene variations influence each other and on other factors that influence the DPD activity. Whether a gene activity score of 1 or 1.5 needs to be assigned in the case of two different genetic variations can only be determined by measuring the enzyme activity (phenotyping). The Canadian Pharmacogenomics Network for Drug Safety (CPNDS) clinical recommendation group has published clinical practice guidelines for CYP2D6 as a treatment decision aid for ER-positive non-metastatic breast cancer patients. The guidelines recommend that alternatives to standard tamoxifen treatments may be considered in CYP2D6 poor or intermediate metabolizers with an emphasis on the use of comprehensive CYP2D6 genotyping panels in guiding treatment decisions.

\n"", ""version"": 0}, ""terms"": [], ""textMarkdown"": {""id"": 1450361940, ""html"": ""

The Canadian Pharmacogenomics Network for Drug Safety (CPNDS) clinical recommendation group has published clinical practice guidelines for CYP2D6 as a treatment decision aid for ER-positive non-metastatic breast cancer patients in the journal Breast Cancer Research and Treatment.\nExcerpts from "
column2: CYP2D6 as a treatment decision aid for ER-positive non-metastatic breast cancer patients: a systematic review with accompanying clinical practice guidelines"
column3:
[Article:30411242] follow:

\\n

Literature review

\\n
\\n
    \\n
  • Evidence was only evaluated regarding the treatment of ER-positive breast cancer with tamoxifen, the recommendations do not apply to ER-negative or triple-negative breast cancer.
    • \\n
  • 48 articles were identified for inclusion and systematically evaluated.
    • \\n
  • Examination of confounding factors based on 38 studies showed that comprehensive genotyping panels being more likely to report a significant association with CYP2D6-survival outcome (P = 0.006).
    • \\n
  • Majority of evidence points toward the influence that CYP2D6 genetic variation exerts on survival outcomes after treatment with tamoxifen.
    • \\n
\\n
\\n

Guidance

\\n
\\n

Which patients should be tested for CYP2D6?
\\n
column4:
\\n
    \\n
  • Genetic testing for CYP2D6 is RECOMMENDED prior to initiation of adjuvant tamoxifen treatment (Grade B\\u2014 Moderate) for postmenopausal women with non-metastatic ER-positive breast cancer in whom tamoxifen is being considered as a therapeutic alternative to aromatase inhibitors (AIs).
    • \\n
  • In cases where initial tamoxifen treatment is being considered, CYP2D6 genotyping should be performed and individuals who are CYP2D6 poor/intermediate metabolizers should opt for 5 years of AI treatment.
    • \\n
  • Genetic testing for CYP2D6 is RECOMMENDED prior to initiation of adjuvant treatment in higher-risk breast cancer patients (Grade B\\u2014moderate) for premenopausal women with non-metastatic ER-positive breast cancer.
    • \\n
  • Without ovarian suppression, aromatase inhibitors (AIs) are not a viable therapeutic alternative in premenopausal women. In such patients, if tamoxifen is the only therapeutic option, CYP2D6 genotyping prior to initiation of treatment may inform dosing decisions.
    • \\n
\\n\\n

Table 1 - Treatment guidelines for non-metastatic ER-positive breast cancer patients based on CYP2D6 activity scores from the publication \\u201cCYP2D6 as a treatment decision aid for ER-positive non-metastatic breast cancer patients: a systematic review with accompanying clinical practice guidelines"

\\nb In individuals receiving tamoxifen, moderate or strong CYP2D6 inhibitors', 'guidelines focuses only on the role of CYP2D6 genotype in the adjuvant treatment of ER+ breast cancer, using the endpoints of recurrence, recurrence-free survival, disease-free survival, distant relapse-free survival, breast cancer specific survival, and overall survival."
column6:
\\n
  • "
column7: CYP2D6 UMs and NMs are expected to achieve therapeutic endoxifen concentrations after administration of tamoxifen and should receive the recommended standard of care doses of tamoxifen. CYP2D6 PMs and IMs (including patients with an activity score of 1.0, see below) are expected to have lower endoxifen concentrations compared to NMs and have a higher risk of breast cancer recurrence, and worse event-free survival compared to NMs.&quot
column8:
\\n
  • "
column9:
For CYP2D6 PMs, a \\u201cstrong\\u201d therapeutic recommendation was provided to recommend alternative hormonal therapy such as an aromatase inhibitor (AI) for postmenopausal women or aromatase inhibitor along with ovarian function suppression in premenopausal women given that these approaches are superior to tamoxifen regardless of CYP2D6 genotype [Articles:26211827, 24881463] and based on knowledge that CYP2D6 PMs patients who switch from tamoxifen to anastrozole do not exhibit an increased risk of recurrence [Article:23213055]. Given that escalation of tamoxifen dose from 20-40 mg/day in CYP2D6 PM significantly increases endoxifen concentrations (but not to concentrations achieved in CYP2D6 NMs [Article:27226358]), the use of an aromatase inhibitor (+/- ovarian function suppression) is recommended in this setting. Tamoxifen 40 mg/day can be considered for CYP2D6 PM if there are contraindications to AI use.\\n
  • "
column10: For CYP2D6 IMs and CYP2D6*10/*10 or CYP2D6*10/decreased function allele, a \\u201cmoderate\\u201d recommendation was made to consider use of an alternative hormonal therapy (i.e. aromatase inhibitor) for postmenopausal women or aromatase inhibitor plus ovarian function suppression in premenopausal women is recommended. In CYP2D6 IMs, if aromatase inhibitors are contraindicated, consideration can be given for the use of a higher FDA-approved dose of tamoxifen (40 mg/day), which is known to result in significantly higher endoxifen concentrations without an increase in toxicity [Article:27226358]. Based on extrapolation from evidence in *10 individuals, a similar recommendation applies to individuals who carry other decreased function alleles resulting in an activity score of 1.0 but with an \\u201coptional\\u201d recommendation, given the paucity of data for this group."

152,Can exondys be advised to limb girdle muscular dystrophy patients?,,,"['circumstances where the benefits outweigh the risks. In general, alternative anesthetics are widely available and effective in patients with MHS.

\n

A list of unsafe halogenated volatile anesthetics or depolarizing muscle relaxants and alternative anesthetics can be found at http://www.mhaus.org/healthcare-professionals/be-prepared/safe-and-unsafe-anesthetics. Individuals who have biallelic (homozygous or compound heterozygous) pathogenic variants in RYR1 generally will have autosomal recessive myopathies and should be managed according to the standard of care for those disorders. Although some may, indeed, have susceptibility to anesthetic agents, the recommendations described here cannot adequately address such patients, and they should be managed by a physician who is knowledgeable regarding those disorders.

\n""}, ""implications"": [""RYR1: Individuals are at increased risk of developing malignant hyperthermia if administered halogenated volatile anesthetics or the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine""], ""lookupKey"": {""RYR1"": ""Malignant Hyperthermia Susceptibility"", ""CACNA1S"": ""No Result""}, ""dosingInformation"": false, ""alternateDrugAvailable"": true, ""otherPrescribingGuidance"": true}, {""id"": ""PA166323528"", ""name"": ""Recommendation Annotation PA166323528"", ""population"": ""general"", ""classification"": {""term"": ""Strong"", ""termId"": ""guidelineStrength:981501930""}, ""relatedChemicals"": [{""id"": ""PA450434"", ""name"": ""methoxyflurane"", ""symbol"": null}], ""text"": {""id"": 1452326647, ""html"": ""

Halogenated volatile anesthetics or the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine are relatively contraindicated in persons with malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS). \n

A list of unsafe halogenated volatile anesthetics or depolarizing muscle relaxants and alternative anesthetics can be found at http://www.mhaus.org/healthcare-professionals/be-prepared/safe-and-unsafe-anesthetics. Based on RYR1 status, halogenated volatile anesthetics or the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine are relatively contraindicated in persons with malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS). They should not be used, except in extraordinary circumstances where the benefits outweigh the risks. In general, alternative anesthetics are widely available and effective in patients with MHS.

\n

Based on RYR1 status, halogenated volatile anesthetics or the depolarizing muscle relaxant succinylcholine are relatively contraindicated in persons with malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS). They should not be used, except in extraordinary circumstances where the benefits outweigh the risks. In general, alternative anesthetics are widely available and effective in patients with MHS.

Alternative Treatment Options:
Alternative opioids that do not rely on CYP2D6 for activation, such as morphine or oxycodone, may be considered. Non-opioid analgesics might also be an option, depending on the type and severity of pain.

If codeine is prescribed despite the poor metabolizer status, careful monitoring for efficacy and side effects is essential.
Regular follow-up appointments to assess pain control and adjust treatment as needed are important.                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Patient Education:
Explain to the patient and caregivers why codeine might not be effective for them and discuss alternative treatment options.
Educate them about potential side effects and the importance of reporting any issues promptly.
Pharmacogenomic Guidelines:
Specific guidelines from pharmacogenomic bodies like the Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) strongly recommend against the use of codeine in CYP2D6 Poor Metabolizers due to the expected lack of efficacy.
Clinical Context:
Other factors, such as patient age, weight, liver function, other medications, and the specific symptoms and needs of the patient, must also be considered in treatment decisions.

column8:
guideline for Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs and CYP2C9. The CPIC authors have evaluated therapeutic dose recommendations for dosing of aceclofenac, aspirin, diclofenac, indomethacin, lumiracoxib, metamizole, nabumetone and naproxen based on CYP2C9 genotypes. They conclude that there is insufficient evidence to provide a recommendation to guide clinical practice at this time.

\\n

column9: Aceclofenac, aspirin, diclofenac, indomethacin, lumiracoxib, metamizole, nabumetone and naproxen. Table S9 includes evidence linking CYP2C9 genotype to aceclofenac, aspirin, diclofenac, indomethacin, lumiracoxib, metamizole, nabumetone and naproxen phenotype. The pharmacokinetics of these drugs are not significantly impacted by CYP2C9 genetic variants in vivo and/or there is insufficient evidence to provide a recommendation to guide clinical practice at this time (CPIC classification of recommendation \\u201cno recommendation\\u201d

column13: Substantial evidence links CYP2C9 genotypes with phenotypic variability in CYP2C9 metabolism and plasma NSAID concentrations, with the majority of studies conducted in healthy volunteers.&quot
column14:
\\n\\n
  • \\n

    "
column15: Although clinical evidence linking genetic variation in CYP2C9 to an increased rate of adverse events with NSAIDs use is scarce, several studies have established an association between CYP2C9 decreased function and no function alleles and elevated NSAID exposure (Figure 1 and Figure S2). Because most NSAID adverse events are dose-dependent, on-target adverse events involving COX inhibition (19-23) it is reasonable to assume that elevated exposure increases the risk of adverse events.&quot
column16:
\\n\\n
  • \\n

    "
column17: CYP2C9 IM and PM phenotypes affect systemic plasma concentrations of NSAIDs by decreasing metabolic clearance and consequently prolonging plasma elimination half-life. Therefore, therapeutic recommendations are broadly organized according to the NSAID plasma elimination half-life in NMs. Where more than two studies reported plasma concentration areaunder-the-curve (AUC), a meta-analysis was conducted to estimate the average impact of CYP2C9 genotype on drug exposure (Figure 1 and Figures S2 to S4).&quot
column18:
\\n\\n
  • \\n

    "
column19: Meloxicam. Meloxicam has a longer half-life (15-20 hours, Table S12) than celecoxib and ibuprofen
column20: thus, impaired meloxicam metabolism is expected to cause sustained elevations in drug exposure. Recommendations for CYP2C9 NMs and IMs with an AS of 1.5 are similar to the short half-life NSAIDs and include initiation of therapy with the standard dose while using the lowest effective dosage for shortest duration capable to achieve treatment goals. For IMs with an AS of 1, reduced metabolism and increased plasma concentrations are expected that may increase probability of toxicities...The recommendations are to either initiate therapy with 50% of the lowest recommended starting dose or choose an alternative therapy, consistent with the recommendations in PMs for short half-life NSAIDs (Table 2). Upward dose titration should not occur until after steady-state is reached (at least seven days), and careful monitoring is recommended. CYP2C9 PMs should be prescribed an alternative therapy because markedly prolonged half-life is expected (i.e., &gt
column21: 100 hours)&quot
column22:
.

\\n\\n
  • \\n

    "
column23: Celecoxib, flurbiprofen, ibuprofen, lornoxicam: Based on current evidence, NMs and IMs with an AS of 1.5 are recommended to initiate therapy with the approved starting dose. Despitehaving mildly reduced metabolism, IMs with an AS of 1.5 do not exhibit significant increases in drug exposure relative to NMs... CYP2C9 IMs with an AS of 1 have reduced metabolism and are expected to exhibit a prolonged drug half-life and higher plasma concentrations compared to NMs, which may increase probability of toxicities.For IMs with an AS of 1, it is recommended to initiate NSAID therapy with the lowest recommended starting dose and titrate to clinical effect with close monitoring for adverse events such as elevated blood pressure and kidney dysfunction during course of therapy. Regarding ibuprofen use, it should be taken into consideration that while the CYP2C9*2 allele alone might not cause a clinically relevant reduction in clearance, its strong linkage with the\\ndecreased function CYP2C8*3 allele may result in impaired R (-) ibuprofen hydroxylation and increased exposure to the parent drug...Individuals with a CYP2C9 PM phenotype (AS of 0) are expected to have markedly reduced metabolism and are expected to exhibit a pronounced prolongation of drug half-life and increase in plasma concentrations, which may increase the probability and/or severity of toxicities...It is recommended to initiate therapy with 25-50% of the lowest recommended starting dose (i.e. 50-75% dose reduction), and careful dose titration to clinical effect. Because drug half-life is significantly prolonged in these patients, upward dose titration should not occur until after steady-state is reached, taking into consideration the PM half-life for each drug
column24: of course, dosing may be stopped or decreased due to toxicity at any time. Treatment with an alternative therapy could also be considered. This could include NSAIDs not primarily metabolized by CYP2C9 (such as aspirin, ketorolac (approved for short term use only), metamizole, naproxen, sulindac, etoricoxib, parecoxib, or valdecoxib), or with pharmacokinetic parameters apparently not impacted by CYP2C9 genetic variants in vivo despite CYP2C9 metabolism in vitro&quot

.', 'Drugs: phenytoin
Genes: CYP2C9
Phenotypes: Poor Metabolizer
Class: Anti Convulsants
Recommendations: CPIC                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Reduced phenytoin metabolism, higher plasma concentrations will increase probability of toxicities.Consider 50% reduction of recommended starting maintenance dose d. Subsequent maintenance doses should be adjusted according to therapeutic drug monitoring and response.                                                                                                    DPWG                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Genetic variation reduces conversion of phenytoin to inactive metabolites. This increases the risk of side effects.The loading dose does not need to be adjusted.
2. For the other doses, use 40-50% of the standard dose and assess the dose based on effect and serum concentration after 7-10 days.
3. Advise the patient to get in touch if side effects (such as ataxia, nystagmus, slurred speech, sedation or rash) occur.                                                                                  FDA                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          May result in higher systemic concentrations and higher adverse reaction risk (central nervous system toxicity). Refer to FDA labeling for specific dosing recommendations. Carriers of CYP2C9*3 alleles may be at increased risk of severe cutaneous adverse reactions. Consider avoiding phenytoin as an alternative to carbamazepine in patients who are CYP2C9*3 carriers. Genotyping is not a substitute for clinical vigilance and patient management.

column9:
1:102-12. Date 19-09-2007 Fact. V Leiden heterozyg: anticoncept. met oestr. 1567 The heterozygously present genetic polymorphism “factor V Leiden” causes an increased tendency to coagulation, resulting in an increased risk of venous thromboembolism. Contraceptives containing oestrogens can increase this risk even further. Recommendation: If the patient has a FAMILY HISTORY WITH A LOT OF THROMBOSIS, or has had a PREVIOUS THROMBOSIS: 1 . Advise the prescriber to avoid the use of contraceptives that contain oestrogens and prescribe a non-hormone contraceptive - such as a copper IUD - as an alternative. One could also opt for a progestogen-only contraceptive method, such as the depot injection, an IUD with levonorgestrel or an implant with etonogestrel. OTHER CASES: 1 . The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group has evaluated therapeutic dose recommendations for hormonal contraceptives for systemic use based on Factor V Leiden (FVL, or F5) genotype [Article:21412232]. Monitoring for Adverse Effects:
Close monitoring for potential side effects, such as headache, diarrhea, nausea, or other PPI-related adverse effects, is crucial.

If managing the dose of omeprazole is challenging, an alternative PPI or other acid-reducing medication that is not primarily metabolized by CYP2C19 may be considered.
Pharmacogenomic Guidelines:
Specific recommendations from organizations like the Dutch Pharmacogenetics Working Group (DPWG) or other relevant professional guidelines may provide detailed guidance for treating Poor Metabolizers of CYP2C19 with omeprazole.

: ']","Indeterminate status in genotype refers to a situation where the genetic test results do not provide a clear or definitive classification of the individual's genetic makeup for a particular gene. This can occur due to various reasons, such as ambiguous test results, insufficient data, or the presence of rare or novel genetic variants that are not well-characterized. As a result, the individual's metabolic status or response to certain drugs related to these genes remains unclear or unknown.

For example, in the context of the provided documents, both the NUDT15 and TPMT genes have an indeterminate status for the drug thioguanine. This means that the patient's ability to metabolize thioguanine cannot be accurately predicted based on the available genetic information.
**Confidence Score: 95%**

Genetic variation increases the risk of severe, possibly fatal toxicity. A reduced conversion of tegafur to inactive metabolites means that

with 25% of the standard dose is recommended.']","Ultrarapid metabolizers (UMs) often require increased dosages or frequency of medications because their bodies metabolize drugs more quickly than normal metabolizers. This rapid metabolism can lead to lower plasma concentrations of the active drug, increasing the probability of pharmacotherapy failure. As a result, the medication may not be effective at standard dosages.

column1: Alternatives are suggested because some drugs may not be effective at any reasonable dosage for UMs due to their rapid metabolism. For example, in the case of tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) metabolized by CYP2D6, UMs are advised to avoid these drugs due to potential lack of efficacy. Instead, drugs not metabolized by CYP2D6, such as bupropion, are recommended.

The Royal Dutch Pharmacists Association - Pharmacogenetics Working Group has evaluated therapeutic dose recommendations for hormonal contraceptives for systemic use based on Factor V Leiden (FVL, or F5) genotype [Article:21412232]. They suggest that in individuals who carry the Factor V Leiden allele and have a family history of thrombotic events, estrogen-containing oral contraceptives should be avoided and alternative forms of contraception used.

166,What are side effects associated wtih DPYD poor metabolism of fluorouracil?,"5-FU has many adverse drug effects when used systemically. The most common adverse effect reported in patients receiving systemic 5-FU treatment was diarrhea. Other common adverse effects include vomiting, nausea, and dehydration. More concerning side effects that require monitoring in patients receiving systemic 5-FU chemotherapy include neutropenia, pyrexia, pulmonary embolism, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia. Leukopenia, leading to an immunocompromised state in these patients, can result in secondary pneumonia or sepsis.[8]

The systemic side effect profile of topically applied 5-FU is minimal due to limited absorption. The most common adverse effect of the topical application of 5-FU is localized skin irritation, leading to ulceration and predisposing patients to infection. Other side effects of topical 5-FU therapy include pruritis, pain, erythema, crusting, and eczematous skin reactions.[1][2]",,"[""Drug: fluorouracil

It's crucial to consult a healthcare professional for appropriate treatment decisions. This information is intended to enhance the understanding of potential drug responses and is not a substitute for medical advice.
Official CPIC Recommendation: Avoid use of 5-fluorouracil or 5-fluorouracil prodrug-based regimens.
Validation of AI- generated CPIC Recommendation (Yes/No): Yes
AI- generated FDA Recommendation: FDA label for fluorouracil advises that patients with partial or no dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) activity, as may occur with certain DPYD genetic variants, are at increased risk for severe, life-threatening, or fatal adverse reactions caused by fluorouracil (e.g., neutropenia, neurotoxicity, and diarrhea). The FDA recommends that physicians consider testing for DPD deficiency in patients who present with unusual or severe toxicity within days of starting treatment.
Official FDA Recommendation: Results in higher adverse reaction risk (severe, life-threatening, or fatal toxicities). No dosage has proven safe in poor metabolizers and insufficient data are available to recommend a dosage in intermediate metabolizers. Withhold or discontinue in the presence of early-onset or unusually severe toxicity.
Validation of AI- generated FDA Recommendation (Yes/No): Yes

AI- generated DPWG Recommendation: Dosing Considerations:
Many guidelines recommend avoiding the use of 5-FU and other fluoropyrimidines in Poor Metabolizers due to the high risk of severe toxicity.
If no alternative treatment options are available, a significant dose reduction (possibly up to 50% or more) may be considered, followed by close monitoring.
Alternative Treatment Options:
Consideration of alternative chemotherapy regimens that do not involve DPYD metabolism is usually preferred.
Therapeutic Monitoring:
If 5-FU must be used, intensive monitoring for toxicity signs, including gastrointestinal symptoms, neutropenia, and skin reactions, is essential.
Frequent blood tests to monitor blood counts, liver function, and other relevant parameters may be necessary.
Patient Education and Support:
Patients should be educated about the high risk of toxicity and the need for prompt reporting of any symptoms.
Supportive care to manage or prevent toxicity might be required.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Pharmacogenomic Testing:
If not already performed, pharmacogenomic testing for DPYD status might be considered to confirm the Poor Metabolizer phenotype and guide treatment decisions.
Multidisciplinary Approach:
Collaboration between oncologists, pharmacists, genetic counselors, and other specialized healthcare providers can help manage the complex treatment needs of these patients.
Clinical Context:
The specific type and stage of cancer, other concurrent medications, and the patient's overall health and preferences must also be considered.
Official DPWG Recommendation: The gene variation increases the risk of severe, potentially fatal toxicity. A reduced conversion of fluorouracil/capecitabine to inactive metabolites means that the normal dose
is an overdose.
Start with 50% of the standard dose or avoid fluorouracil and capecitabine. After starting treatment, the dose should be adjusted based on toxicity and effectiveness. In a study involving 17 patients with genotype 1/2846T, the average dose after
titration was 64% of the standard dose. For 51 patients with genotype 1/1236A, the average dose after titration was 74% of the standard dose. determine the residual DPD activity in mononuclear cells from peripheral blood and adjust the initial dose based on phenotype and genotype, or avoid fluorouracil and
capecitabine. Tegafur is not an alternative, as this is also metabolised by DPD.

column1: 1. **Neutropenia**: A significant decrease in neutrophils, a type of white blood cell, which increases the risk of infection.
2. **Neurotoxicity**: Damage to the nervous system, which can manifest as various neurological symptoms.

: ""]","For a patient with HLA-B*15:02 positive status, safer alternatives to carbamazepine should be considered due to the significantly increased risk of severe skin reactions such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). column22: 1427-33.\n27\n.']","CYP2C9 is a key enzyme involved in the metabolism of several anticoagulants, including acenocoumarol and phenprocoumon. Genetic polymorphisms in CYP2C9, such as the CYP2C9*2 and CYP2C9*3 alleles, can significantly affect the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of these drugs.

column1: 1. **Interaction with Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs)**: Allelic variants of CYP2C9 can modify the interaction between NSAIDs and coumarin anticoagulants, potentially altering the effectiveness and safety of the anticoagulant therapy (Visser LE et al., 2005).

2. **Anticoagulation Status**: Polymorphisms in CYP2C9 can affect the anticoagulation status of patients on phenprocoumon, leading to variations in drug metabolism and therapeutic outcomes (Schalekamp T et al., 2004).

3. **Bleeding Complications**: Patients with CYP2C9*2 or CYP2C9*3 alleles are at an increased risk of bleeding complications when on acenocoumarol or phenprocoumon, due to reduced metabolism of these drugs (Visser LE et al., 2004).

4. **Delayed Stabilization**: Carriers of the CYP2C9*3 allele may experience delayed stabilization of acenocoumarol therapy, necessitating careful monitoring and dose adjustments (Schalekamp T et al., 2004).

5. **Overanticoagulation**: The presence of CYP2C9*2 or CYP2C9*3 alleles can increase the risk of overanticoagulation in patients on acenocoumarol or phenprocoumon, which can lead to adverse effects (Visser LE et al., 2004).
**Confidence Score: 90%**
**References:**
- Visser LE et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther 2005
- Schalekamp T et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther 2004
- Visser LE et al. Thromb Haemost 2004
- Schalekamp T et al. Clin Pharmacol Ther 2004

170,Which are the antidiabetic medications influenced by G6PD metabolism?,,https://www.pharmgkb.org/chemical/PA164712711/prescribingInfo,"['{""citations"": [{""id"": 15135762, ""title"": ""Expanded Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) Guideline for Medication Use in the Context of G6PD Genotype."", ""_sameAs"": ""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/36049896"", ""authors"": [""Gammal Roseann S"", ""Pirmohamed Munir"", ""Somogyi Andrew A"", ""Morris Sarah A"", ""Formea Christine M"", ""Elchynski Amanda L"", ""Oshikoya Kazeem A"", ""McLeod Howard L"", ""Haidar Cyrine E"", ""Whirl-Carrillo Michelle"", ""Klein Teri E"", ""Caudle Kelly E"", ""Relling Mary V""], ""crossReferences"": [{""id"": 1451882620, ""resource"": ""PubMed"", ""resourceId"": ""36049896"", ""_url"": ""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/36049896"", ""version"": 0}, {""id"": 1451882621, ""resource"": ""DOI"", ""resourceId"": ""10.1002/cpt.2735"", ""_url"": ""http://dx.doi.org/10.1002%2Fcpt.2735"", ""version"": 0}], ""day"": -1, ""hasKeyword"": true, ""journal"": ""Clinical pharmacology and therapeutics"", ""meshDiseases"": [], ""meshTerms"": [], ""month"": 9, ""nonHuman"": false, ""objCls"": ""Literature"", ""pediatric"": false, ""pgkbPublication"": true, ""pubDate"": ""2022-09-01T00:00:00-07:00"", ""summary"": ""Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is associated with development of acute hemolytic anemia in the setting of oxidative stress, which can be caused by medication exposure. Regulatory agencies worldwide warn against the use of certain medications in G6PD deficient persons, but in many cases, this information is conflicting, and the clinical evidence is sparse. This guideline provides information on using G6PD genotype as part of the diagnosis of G6PD deficiency and classifies medications that have been previously implicated as unsafe in G6PD deficient individuals by one or more sources. We classify these medications as high, medium, or low-to-no risk based on a systematic review of the published evidence of the gene-drug associations and regulatory warnings. In patients with G6PD deficiency, high risk medications should be avoided, medium risk medications should be used with caution, and low-to-no risk medications can be used with standard precautions, without regard to G6PD phenotype. This new document replaces the prior Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium guideline for rasburicase therapy in the context of G6PD genotype (updates at www.cpicpgx.org)."", ""terms"": [{""id"": 1451577480, ""resource"": ""PGx Paper Types"", ""term"": ""Implementation"", ""termId"": ""pgxPaperTypes:1451577480""}], ""type"": ""Literature"", ""version"": 2, ""year"": 2022}], ""guideline"": {""objCls"": ""Guideline Annotation"", ""id"": ""PA166279481"", ""name"": ""Annotation of CPIC Guideline for chlorpropamide, dabrafenib, gliclazide, glimepiride, glipizide, mesalazine, moxifloxacin, nicorandil, nitrofurazone, probenecid, quinacrine, sodium nitrate, sulfacetamide, tolazamide, trametinib and G6PD"", ""alternateDrugAvailable"": false, ""cancerGenome"": false, ""crossReferences"": [{""id"": 1451896981, ""resource"": ""URL"", ""resourceId"": ""https://cpicpgx.org/guidelines/cpic-guideline-for-g6pd/"", ""_url"": ""https://cpicpgx.org/guidelines/cpic-guideline-for-g6pd/"", ""version"": 0}], ""dosingInformation"": false, ""hasTestingInfo"": false, ""history"": [], ""literature"": [{""id"": 15135762, ""title"": ""Expanded Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) Guideline for Medication Use in the Context of G6PD Genotype."", ""_sameAs"": ""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/36049896"", ""crossReferences"": [{""id"": 1451882620, ""resource"": ""PubMed"", ""resourceId"": ""36049896"", ""_url"": ""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/36049896""}, {""id"": 1451882621, ""resource"": ""DOI"", ""resourceId"": ""10.1002/cpt.2735"", ""_url"": ""http://dx.doi.org/10.1002%2Fcpt.2735""}], ""objCls"": ""Literature"", ""pubDate"": ""2022-09-01T00:00:00-07:00"", ""terms"": [{""id"": 1451577480, ""resource"": ""PGx Paper Types"", ""term"": ""Implementation"", ""termId"": ""pgxPaperTypes:1451577480""}], ""type"": ""Literature""}], ""otherPrescribingGuidance"": false, ""pediatric"": true, ""pediatricMarkdown"": {""id"": 1451994540, ""html"": ""

These medications are classified based on their risk of causing acute hemolytic anemia in individuals with G6PD deficiency.

Regulatory agencies worldwide warn against the use of certain medications in G6PD deficient persons, but in many cases, this information is conflicting, and the clinical evidence is sparse. This guideline provides information on using G6PD genotype as part of the diagnosis of G6PD deficiency and classifies medications that have been previously implicated as unsafe in G6PD deficient individuals by one or more sources. We classify these medications as high, medium, or low-to-no risk based on a systematic review of the published evidence of the gene-drug associations and regulatory warnings. In patients with G6PD deficiency, high risk medications should be avoided, medium risk medications should be used with caution, and low-to-no risk medications can be used with standard precautions, without regard to G6PD phenotype. This new document replaces the prior Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium guideline for rasburicase therapy in the context of G6PD genotype (updates at www.cpicpgx.org)."", ""terms"": [{""id"": 1451577480, ""resource"": ""PGx Paper Types"", ""term"": ""Implementation"", ""termId"": ""pgxPaperTypes:1451577480""}], ""type"": ""Literature"", ""version"": 2, ""year"": 2022}], ""guideline"": {""objCls"": ""Guideline Annotation"", ""id"": ""PA166279481"", ""name"": ""Annotation of CPIC Guideline for chlorpropamide, dabrafenib, gliclazide, glimepiride, glipizide, mesalazine, moxifloxacin, nicorandil, nitrofurazone, probenecid, quinacrine, sodium nitrate, sulfacetamide, tolazamide, trametinib and G6PD"", ""alternateDrugAvailable"": false, ""cancerGenome"": false, ""crossReferences"": [{""id"": 1451896981, ""resource"": ""URL"", ""resourceId"": ""https://cpicpgx.org/guidelines/cpic-guideline-for-g6pd/"", ""_url"": ""https://cpicpgx.org/guidelines/cpic-guideline-for-g6pd/"", ""version"": 0}], ""dosingInformation"": false, ""hasTestingInfo"": false, ""history"": [], ""literature"": [{""id"": 15135762, ""title"": ""Expanded Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC) Guideline for Medication Use in the Context of G6PD Genotype."", ""_sameAs"": ""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/36049896"", ""crossReferences"": [{""id"": 1451882620, ""resource"": ""PubMed"", ""resourceId"": ""36049896"", ""_url"": ""https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/36049896""}, {""id"": 1451882621, ""resource"": ""DOI"", ""resourceId"": ""10.1002/cpt.2735"", ""_url"": ""http://dx.doi.org/10.1002%2Fcpt.2735""}], ""objCls"": ""Literature"", ""pubDate"": ""2022-09-01T00:00:00-07:00"", ""terms"": [{""id"": 1451577480, ""resource"": ""PGx Paper Types"", ""term"": ""Implementation"", ""termId"": ""pgxPaperTypes:1451577480""}], ""type"": ""Literature""}], ""otherPrescribingGuidance"": false, ""pediatric"": true, ""pediatricMarkdown"": {""id"": 1451994540, ""html"": ""

column1: 171,What are the adverse outcomes associated with MTHFR rs1801133 AA genotype in methotrexate administration?,"Patients with the rs1801133 AA genotype and Arthritis who are treated with methotrexate may have an increased risk of toxicity as compared to patients with the GG genotype.
